title: Total factor productivity in South African manufacturing firms 2010–17: CIT-IRP5 panel v4.0
text:
2021-12-01




Total factor productivity in South African manufacturing firms 2010–17: CIT-IRP5 panel v4.0
Coauthor: Friedrich Kreuser
Date: December 1, 2021
PDF


Abstract (click to expand)

We update Kreuser and Newman’s (2018) total factor productivity estimates for the South African manufacturing sector using administrative data from 2009–17. We use standard implementations of the Ackerberg et al. (2015) and Wooldridge (2009) productivity estimators and introduce an implementation of the former that converges to elasticities inside the unit interval more consistently. Limited productivity growth is found for the period 2010–17, with the majority of variance in sectoral productivity attributable to variance in allocative efficiency. We find that industries that have higher share sales allocated to more productive firms are generally more capital intensive and have significantly higher capital elasticities of output while only having slightly higher labour elasticities of output.

title: Teaching
text:
University of Michigan, Spring 2026: Econ 251 (Introductory Econometrics and Statistics), TA for Dr. Asenka Asenova.
University of Michigan, Fall 2025: Econ 251 (Introductory Econometrics and Statistics), TA for Dr. Asenka Asenova.
University of Pretoria, 2018-2019: EKN 214 & 234 (Intermediate Macroeconomics I & II), TA for Dr Heinrich Bohlmann.

title: Home
text: Welcome! I am a PhD student in Economics at the University of Michigan. My interests lie in International Trade, Macroeconomics, and Applied Econometrics. Before starting my PhD, I helped build the administrative tax database at the National Treasury of South Africa, where I worked with the UN, World Bank, and Economic Research Southern Africa. I also spent a year at Yale University as part of the Tobin Centre Predoc program.

text:

Electricity Infrastructure and Spatial Development with Wei Xiang
